name: Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10, Ubiquinone)
summary: An antioxidant and mitochondrial cofactor that supports cellular energy production, studied for fatigue, neuroprotection, and mood disorders.
description: Coenzyme Q10 (ubiquinone, ubiquinol) is a naturally occurring compound in the electron transport chain that plays a key role in ATP production and cellular energy metabolism. As both an antioxidant and mitochondrial cofactor, it has been investigated in cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative disorders, and psychiatric conditions. Emerging evidence suggests possible benefits for depression, chronic fatigue, and mitochondrial dysfunction–related syndromes. It is generally safe and well tolerated.

metadata.natural_source: Endogenously synthesized; found in meat, fish, nuts, spinach, broccoli
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

contraindications: Caution with anticoagulant therapy (may reduce warfarin effectiveness)

sections.text: CoQ10 functions as an essential cofactor in the electron transport chain, facilitating ATP production. It also acts as a potent antioxidant, reducing oxidative stress and protecting mitochondrial and neuronal membranes from damage. These mechanisms support energy metabolism and neuroprotection, which may contribute to psychiatric and neurological benefits.

adult.note: Higher doses (up to 1200 mg/day) studied in Parkinson’s and neurodegeneration.

sections.text: Onset: several weeks; Duration: sustained with continuous use.

serious: Potential interaction reducing effectiveness of warfarin

other: Absorption is improved when taken with fatty meals.
Ubiquinol form may have superior bioavailability.

items: INR if patient is on warfarin

sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; commonly used in older adults

sections.text: No taper required; can be discontinued without withdrawal effects.

items: Consider for patients with treatment-resistant fatigue or mitochondrial involvement.
Often used in neurodegenerative disease adjunct trials.
Combination with other mitochondrial nutrients (L-carnitine, alpha-lipoic acid) may enhance effects.

items.label: Young AJ et al. Coenzyme Q10 and neurodegenerative disease. Neurochem Res. 2007

seo.title: Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10): Antioxidant and Mitochondrial Supplement
seo.description: Learn about CoQ10’s role in mitochondrial function, neuroprotection, and fatigue. Includes dosing, safety, evidence, and psychiatric relevance.
